discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Ody said it

"It worded kind of poorly but Preset Security Policies are either Standard (balanced) or Strict (Strict)."

comments.content: It worded kind of poorly but Preset Security Policies are either Standard (balanced) or Strict (Strict).

discussion.content: Does balanced baseline protection mean standard preset security policy? It is quite vague and I cannot find any references. I found that standard policy puts problematic emails into spam folder and strict policy quarantines them.

questions.question_text:
Note: This section contains one or more sets of questions with the same scenario and problem. Each question presents a unique solution to the problem. You must determine whether the solution meets the stated goals. More than one solution in the set might solve the problem. It is also possible that none of the solutions in the set solve the problem.

After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return. As a result these questions do not appear on the Review Screen.

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription and use Microsoft Defender for Office 365.

You need to implement a threat policy that will apply a balanced baseline protection profile to protect against spam, phishing, and malware.

Solution: You create a Standard preset security policy.

Does this meet the goal?

comments.content: You are correct. They put very little effort into checking to see if they had the right answer on this one. Hopefully, it will be updated at some point.

discussion.content:
The answer is wrong.
Applies to high-risk users:
You need to configure the Conditions section to include "Sign-in risk" and set it to high.
Requires multifactor authentication (MFA):
In the Grant section, select "Require multifactor authentication."

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.

You need to create a Conditional Access policy named Policy1 that meets the following requirements:

• Applies to high-risk users
• Requires multifactor authentication (MFA)

Which two settings should you configure? To answer, select the appropriate settings in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

comments.content:
Not fully correct.
We need "Require authentication strength" to be able to select "Passwordless MFA".
Simple MFA is not good enough here.

Not quite correct. From the URL you provided...
1. Require multifactor authentication. "7. Under Access controls > Grant, select Grant access, Require multifactor authentication, and select Select."
2. Windows Azure Service Management API. "6. Under Target resources > Resources (formerly cloud apps) > Include > Select resources, choose Windows Azure Service Management API, and select Select."

discussion.content: Require authentication strength, Windows Azure Service Management API

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.

You plan to create a Conditional Access policy named Policy1.

You need to ensure that only Passwordless MFA authentication methods are used when administrators attempt to access the Azure portal. Azure PowerShell, or Azure Command-Line Interface (CLI).

How should you configure Policy1? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

comments.content:
Tested
Policy 1 - Device 1 and 3
Policy 2 - Device 1 only
guys please note....Endpoint Security Antivirus policies in Intune are not applicable to Linux devices because Intune policies for Defender Antivirus are specifically designed for Windows....

discussion.content:
Policy1: Device1 or Device3 only
Policy2: Device1 only
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/endpoint-security-antivirus-policy
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-endpoint/device-control-deploy-manage-intune

1. Microsoft Defender Antivirus (Policy1)
Supported OS: Windows 10/11, Windows Server, and Linux
Not Supported on: Android, macOS (uses different security measures)

2. Device Control (Policy2)
Supported OS: Windows 10/11, Windows Server
Not Supported on: Linux, Android, macOS

comments.content:
Policy 2 : device control supports windows and macos 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-endpoint/device-control-overview

discussion.content:
Policy 1: Device 1 only
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/mem/intune/protect/endpoint-security-policy#create-an-endpoint-security-policy
Policy 2: Device 1 only 
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-endpoint/device-control-deploy-manage-intune

comments.content: Android is supported by Antivirus but it is applied as an app - NOT with the "Microsoft Defender Antivirus Policy". The first question is not about general Antivirus support. It is about the policies.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 tenant.

You plan to manage incidents in the tenant by using the Microsoft Defender XDR.

Which Microsoft service source will appear on the Incidents page of the Microsoft Defender portal?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-xdr/incident-queue

Can be both Defender for Cloud and Defender for Identity

Specify incidents that contain alerts from one or more of the following:
Microsoft Defender for Identity
Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps
Microsoft Defender for Endpoint
Microsoft Defender XDR
Microsoft Defender for Office 365
App Governance
Microsoft Entra ID Protection
Microsoft Data Loss Prevention
Microsoft Defender for Cloud
Microsoft Sentinel
Microsoft Purview Insider Risk Management

Selected Answer: C
C. Microsoft Defender for Cloud

In the Microsoft Defender portal, incidents related to your Microsoft 365 tenant will be shown from Microsoft Defender for Cloud. Microsoft Defender for Cloud provides unified security management and advanced threat protection across hybrid cloud workloads, which is integrated into the Microsoft Defender portal for managing incidents and alerts.
